Below is a timeline of events in [[Hamilton, Ontario]] [[Canada]].
[[Image:Joseph Brant 2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Joseph Brant]], 1786]]
==Before 1800== * According to all records from local historians, this district was inhabited by the [[Neutral Indians]] who called it '''ATTIWANDARONIA.''' <ref name=SAGA>{{cite book|title=Saga of a City|first=Milton |last=Watson|publisher=The Hamilton Spectator|year=1938}}</ref>
* 1616- Like most of the Americas south of the tree line, the original inhabitants of the Hamilton area were [[First Nations|Indians]]. The first European to visit what is now Hamilton was probably [[Ãtienne BrÃ»lÃ©]] in 1616. Lasalle also visited the area, a fact commemorated at a park in nearby Burlington.<ref name="HAMBIO1-p143">{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Hamilton Biography (Vol I, 1791â1875)|first=Thomas Melville |last=Bailey|publisher=W.L. Griffin Ltd|page=143|year=1981}}</ref>
* 1650- The [[Iroquois]] Indians fought the [[Neutral Nation|Neutrals]] in a great battle on the foot of present day ''Emerald Street''. This area was the end of an old Indian trail that led to the Dundas Valley. The Iroquois landed from [[canoes]] and won the battle because they had obtained [[guns]] from the [[Dutch (ethnic group)|Dutch]], and the Neutrals refused to trade with the whites. So many Neutrals were slain that the mound where they were buried could still be seen after 250 years (1900).<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1780- About the year that both [[Robert Land]] and [[Richard Beasley]] arrived.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1784- About 10,000 [[United Empire Loyalists]] are settled in what is now southern Ontario, chiefly in [[Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ontario|Niagara]], around the [[Bay of Quinte]], and along the [[St. Lawrence River]] between [[Lake Ontario]] and [[Montreal]]. They are soon followed by many more Americans, some of them not so much ardent loyalists but attracted nonetheless by the availability of cheap, arable land. At the same time large numbers of Iroquois loyal to Britain arrive from the United States and are settled on reserves west of Lake Ontario. Kingston and Hamilton became important settlements as a result of the influx of Loyalists.<ref name=LOYALISTS>{{cite web| title =United Empire Loyalists' Association of Canada| url=http://www.uelac.org/ | accessdate = 2007-01-28}}</ref>
* 1788- (1788â1793) The townships at the [[Head-of-the-Lake]] were surveyed and named. The area was first known as The Head-of-the-Lake for its location at the western end of Lake Ontario.<ref name=headlake>{{cite web| title =Chronology of the Regional Municipality of Hamilton-Ontario| url=http://epe.lac-bac.gc.ca/100/200/301/ic/can_digital_collections/cultural_landmarks/twps.html| accessdate = 2007-01-09}}</ref>
* 1790- Richard Beasley occupied ''Burlington Heights'' (now the site of ''Dundurn'' and ''Harvey Parks'') in 1790 & was granted land by the Crown in 1799. A local entrepreneur, Beasley's business ventures included fur trading, land acquisition and establishment of a grist mill in [[Ancaster, Ontario|Ancaster]]. He was a member of the legislative assembly of [[Upper Canada]] from 1791 to 1804 and was appointed colonel of the 2nd regiment of the York militia in 1809. Financial difficulties forced Beasley to sell lands at Burlington Heights, but it was purchased in 1832 by [[Allan MacNab|Sir Allan Napier MacNab]] who built [[Dundurn Castle]] on foundations of Beasley's brick home.<ref name="HAMBIO1">{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Hamilton Biography (Vol I, 1791â1875)|first=Thomas Melville |last=Bailey|publisher=W.L. Griffin Ltd|year=1981}}</ref>
* 1791- Barton township established originally in Lincoln township. Eventually becomes part of Wentworth County in 1816.<ref name="headlake"/>
* 1791- a total of 31 families are recorded as having settled at the ''Head-of-the-Lake'' (present day Hamilton).<ref name=FOOTSTEPS>{{cite book|title=Footsteps In Time: Exploring Hamilton's heritage neighbourhoods|first=Bill |last=Manson |publisher=North Shore Publishing Inc|year=2003|isbn= 1-896899-22-6}}</ref>
* 1791- Like [[British North America]] itself, the Six Nations confederacy was torn apart by the [[American Revolution]]. Indians loyal to the Crown, under their leader Captain [[Joseph Brant]], were settled in several nearby areas of what became Upper Canada in 1791 and ultimately Ontario in 1867.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1792- Administratively, the whole area was part of the Nassau District, which was renamed the Home District in 1792. Additionally, parts of the area were separately incorporated into the West Riding of [[York County, Ontario|York County]] and First Riding of [[Lincoln County, Ontario|Lincoln County]]. In 1798, most of the future Hamilton became part of Niagara District while remaining in Lincoln County.<ref name=barton2>{{cite web| title =A History of the city of Hamilton| url=http://epe.lac-bac.gc.ca/100/200/301/ic/can_digital_collections/cultural_landmarks/hamhist.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-09}}</ref>
* 1795- First Lodge of [[Free Masons]], Barton Lodge. (November 20)<ref name=SAGA/>
==1800â1829== * 1801â Concession 2 lot 14, Barton Township was part of the original [[Crown Grant]] to [[John Askin]] on July 10, 1801. He sold to [[Nathaniel Hughson]] senior who sold to [[James Durand]] around 1806.<ref name=barton>{{cite web| title =Gore Park, Barton Township| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Gore+Park.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* 1801â First log court house.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1801â First documented murder case in Hamilton. Victim's name was ''Bartholomew London''.<ref name=murder>{{cite web| title =First documented murder in Hamilton: 1801| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Murder+1801-1899.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* 1803â [[John Ryckman]], born in Barton township, described the area in 1803 as he remembered it: "The city in 1803 was all forest. The shores of the bay were difficult to reach or see because they were hidden by a thick, almost impenetrable mass of trees and undergrowth...Bears ate pigs, so settlers warred on bears. Wolves gobbled sheep and geese, so they hunted and trapped wolves. They also held organized raids on rattlesnakes on the mountainside. There was plenty of game. Many a time have I seen a deer jump the fence into my back yard, and there were millions of pigeons which we clubbed as they flew low."<ref name="barton2"/>
* 1809â Talk of creating a townsite at what is now the intersection of [[John Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|John]] and [[Main Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Main Streets]] arose as early as 1809, but the war delayed the scheme until 1816 when [[George Hamilton (politician)|George Hamilton]] and Nathaniel Hughson successfully promoted Hamilton as the judicial centre for the counties of Halton and Wentworth (the Gore District).<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1812â The town of Hamilton was conceived by George Hamilton when he purchased the Durand farm shortly after the [[War of 1812]].<ref name=HAMBIO1/>
* 1813â Two American schooners, the [[Hamilton (schooner)|Hamilton]] and the [[Scourge (Schooner)|Scourge]], capsized in Lake Ontario in 1813.<ref name=hamsco>{{cite web| title =Hamilton-Scourge web site| url=http://www.hamilton-scourge.city.hamilton.on.ca/| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1813â June 5â6 â British win [[Battle of Stoney Creek]].<ref name=stoneycreek>{{cite web| title =Battlefield House Museum Battle of Stoney Creek 1813| url=http://www.battlefieldhouse.ca/billy_battle.asp| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1813â Eleven men hanged for treason right across the street from where Dundurn Castle eventually gets built.<ref name=firstelect>{{cite web| title = Chronology of Cities, Towns and Townships of Hamilton| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Townships.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* 1813â Hamilton laid out as a village.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1814â Wm. Sheldon opened the first store at the corner of [[King Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|King Street]] and John Street.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1815â A chopping mill is the first industry in Hamilton, Ontario.<ref name=HISINDI>{{cite web| title = History of Industry in Hamilton, Ontario| url=http://epe.lac-bac.gc.ca/100/205/301/ic/cdc/industrial/intro.htm| accessdate = 2009-07-24}}</ref>
* 1815â George Hamilton, a settler and local politician, established a town site in the northern portion Barton Township after the war in 1815. He kept several east-west roads which were originally Indian trails, but the north-south streets were on a regular grid pattern. Streets were designated "East" or "West" if they crossed [[James Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|James Street]] or Highway 6. Streets were designated "North" or "South" if they crossed King Street or Highway 8.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1816â Barton township population is 668.<ref name=bartont>{{cite web| title =Barton township population: 1816| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Barton+Census+1816.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* 1816â Hamilton becomes a village.<ref name=headlake />
* 1817â Barton township population is 800.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1817â First common school on land now occupied by city. It was on King Street, east of [[Wellington Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Wellington Street]].<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1821â First Hamilton School opened. A private school with John Law as master.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1824â First [[Methodist]] church, Now First United.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1827â Growth was aided in 1827 by a channel cut to link [[Burlington Bay]] directly with Lake Ontario, thus improving its marine transportation.<ref name="headlake"/>
* 1829â First newspaper, ''Gore Balance'', published by Bartimus Ferguson.<ref name=SAGA/>
==1830â1839== * 1830â Last man to stand in [[pillory]].<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1832â First bound book, ''Samuel Thomson's New Guide to Health'' published by Smith and Hackstaff.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1832â [[Cholera]] swept the city.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1833â George Hamiltonâs settlement was incorporated as a police village in 1833. On January 8, 1833 the Legislature passed a further act "To define the limits of the Town of Hamilton, in the District of Gore, and to establish a police station and public market therein."<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1833â When the Town of Hamilton was incorporated in 1833, one of the first orders of business, after a closely fought election where 3 out of the 4 candidates had no opposition, was to find a suitable place for the town board to meet. For the first few years they made do with meeting in local taverns such as Thomas Wilson's inn on the corner of John and [[Jackson Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Jackson Streets]].<ref name=cityhall>{{cite web| title =City Hall town meetings at local Taverns- 1833| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/City+Hall.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* 1833â The Garland, a local newspaper, publishes a synopsis, Hamilton contained "about one hundred and twenty dwelling houses and upwards of one thousand inhabitants" and then went on to list 4 public buildings, 7 taverns, 16 stores, 2 watchmakers, 2 saddlers, 4 merchant tailors, 4 cabinet makers, 4 boot and shoe makers, 2 bakers, 4 newspapers, 1 druggist, 1 tin and sheet iron manufactory, 1 hatter and 3 millineries. (February 16, 1833)<ref name="headlake"/>
* 1834â Beach Canal opens and population now at 2000.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1835â [[James Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|James Street]] was the ''Lake Road'' and in 1835, James Street was extended south, but was interrupted by a [[bog]] at [[Hunter Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Hunter Street]] which eventually (1844) was drained out and graded.<ref name="FOOTSTEPS"/>
* 1835â Sir Allan MacNab completed Dundurn Castle, his stately home, in 1835.<ref name=macnab>{{cite book| last = Bailey| first = Melville| title = The History of Dundurn Castle and Sir Allan MacNab | date = 1987 (reprint)| pages = 1â38}}</ref>
* 1835â Hamilton's first Bank was the Gore Bank of Hamilton. Chartered in 1835 and opened on Monday May 2, 1836.<ref name=Bank>{{cite web| title = Fast Facts from Hamilton's Past| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Fast+Facts.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-08 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060905060213/http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Fast+Facts.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-09-05}}</ref>
* 1835â One of Hamilton's early newspapers is published by [[George Perkins Boothesby Bull]]; ''The Hamilton Gazette, and General Advertiser''. Newspaper lasts until 1856.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1836â George Hamilton, the city's founder, died on February 20, 1836. His body was buried at the family burial plot on the family's own farm. It is now part of ''Mountain Side Park''. The monument (tombstone) at the Hamilton cemetery wasn't put there until 1894. (George Hamilton's body was not buried at the Hamilton cemetery).<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1836â Hamilton's growth continues. City's boundaries now include The Bay to the north, The mountain ([[Niagara Escarpment]]) to the south, [[Queen Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Queen Street]] to the west and Wellington Street to the east.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1836â Hamilton Waterworks Company incorporated.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1837â Sir Allan MacNab, A boy soldier in the War of 1812, he led Gore militia to crush insurgents in the [[Rebellion of 1837]] for which he was knighted the following year.<ref name="macnab"/>
* 1838â Sir Allan MacNab, is knighted.<ref name="macnab"/>
* 1838â St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church on ''Park Street'' is completed.<ref name=STMARYS>{{cite book|title=Hamilton: An Illustrated History|first=John C. |last=Weaver |publisher=James Lorimer & Company Publishers|year=1982|isbn= 0-88862-593-6}}</ref>
==1840â1849== * 1842â First municipal council. The first elections are held and 26 people are chosen to represent the townships of Gore.<ref name="firstelect"/>
* 1843â First city owned fire engines.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1846â Hamilton received its city charter in June-9, 1846 by an act of Parliament, 9 Victoria Chapter 73. 3 newspapers, 2 lending libraries, 3 bookstores, 5 common schools, all rented; 2 boys' schools, 3 ladies' seminaries.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/><ref name=HENLEY>{{cite book |last= Henley |first= Brian |title= 1846 Hamilton: From a frontier town to the Ambitious City |publisher= North Shore Publishing |year=1995 |isbn= 0-9698460-7-X cloth}}</ref>
* 1846â The first telegraph wire in Canada is strung between Hamilton and Toronto on December 1846.<ref>{{cite web| title = History of Industry in Hamilton, Ontario| url = http://collections.ic.gc.ca/industrial/intro.htm|archivedate = 2006-02-06|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060206234910/collections.ic.gc.ca/industrial/intro.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-08}}</ref>
* 1846â ''The Hamilton Spectator'' newspaper is born. (still going strong today).<ref name=CANTIM>{{cite web| title = United Province of Canada Timeline Canadian Encyclopedia| url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCETimelineBrowse&Params=A3PER22SRT1| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1847â [[Colin Campbell Ferrie]] becomes Hamilton's first Mayor.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1847â [[Hugh Cossart Baker, Sr.]] establishes the first life insurance company in Canada (21 August 1847); the [[Canada Life Assurance Company]], with Baker as its president, manager and actuary. (Father of Hamilton telephone pioneer; [[Hugh Cossart Baker, Jr.]])<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1848â King and [[James Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|James Streets]] [[macadamized]].<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1849â 92 deaths recorded from [[cholera]].<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1849â Sir [[William Osler]], "Father of Modern Medicine" (born: July 12, 1849). Raised largely in [[Dundas, Ontario]].<ref name=WOSLER>{{cite web| title =Dictionary of Canadian Biography: Sir William Osler| url=http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=7631| accessdate = 2007-01-28}}</ref>
==1850â1859== * 1850â First lighting of streets by gas.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1851â First land bought by the Board of Education.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1852â First orphanage asylum. Population now at 10,300.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1853â First union-journeymen [[carpenters]] formed union and went on strike. First street numbers on buildings.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1854â the newly renamed [[Great Western Railway (Ontario)]] became Hamiltonâs first functioning railway in 1854. Completion of this railway and the Niagara Suspension Bridge transforms Hamilton into a major centre and part of the American immigration route from [[New York]] or [[Boston]] to [[Chicago]] or [[Milwaukee]].<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1854â September 11, [[Allan Napier MacNab|Sir Allan Napier MacNab]] becomes the [[List of Joint Premiers of the Province of Canada|Premier]] of Canada West, the only Prime Minister of Canada that Hamilton has ever produced. (The Joint Premiers of the Province of Canada, who were the heads of government of the Province of Canada from the 1841 unification of Upper Canada and Lower Canada until Confederation in 1867. Each administration was led by two men, one from Canada West (now [[Ontario]]) and one from Canada East (now [[Quebec]]). Officially, one of them at any given time had the title of Premier while the other had the title of deputy.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1854â Cholera epidemic- more than 600 deaths.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1855â Hamilton's core boasted a sewer system, graded streets and planked sidewalks. Stumps, boulders, and rocks were finally removed from the streets, animals were banned from wandering freely on the new thoroughfares.<ref name="FOOTSTEPS"/>
* 1855â [[Grand Lodge of Canada]] is formed in Hamilton, Ontario (10 November 1855). The National Office of the Supreme Council 33Â° of the Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite of Freemasonry of Canada whose Grand Orient is in Hamilton, Ontario, is located adjacent to this historic Scottish Rite building.
* 1856â First use of [[chloroform]] in Hamilton.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1856â [[Daniel C. Gunn]] engine shop on Wellington Street North, Hamilton, Ontario, produces first Canadian-built locomotives.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1857â 57 passengers were killed when a train derailed near the [[Desjardins Canal]].<ref name=DESJARDINS>{{cite web| title = Desjardins Canal Disaster| url=https://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Desjardins+Canal+Disaster.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-28}}</ref>
* 1857â When the Great Western railroad made the present opening for the Desjardins Canal, the bones of a [[mammoth]] were found.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1858â ''The Hamilton Times'' newspaper begins publishing 9 January 1858. The newspaper lasts until 1920.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1858â Last man imprisoned here for debt.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1859â Mayor elected by the people. [[Henry McKinstry]] first elected mayor.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1859â Last public execution.<ref name="SAGA"/>
==1860â1869== * 1860â First tap water in the city.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1860â The ''Crystal Palace'' opened up at ''Victoria Park'' 20 September 1860. It was home to the area's largest fall fair for many years. The local ''Hamilton Herald'' newspaper was quoted as saying on 22 September 1890, "The Carnival of Venice, The Paris Exposition or the World's Fair in Chicago will be nowhere tomorrow when the great Central Fair is opened at the Crystal Palace Groundsw in this city." The structure was demolished in 1891.<ref name=HAMTIMES>{{cite book|title=Hamilton our Lives and Times|first=Brian |last=Henley |publisher=The Hamilton Spectator|year=1993|isbn= 0-9697255-0-7}}</ref>
* 1860â First railway sleeping car built in Hamilton.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1862â The city had invested in the Great Western Railway (Ontario) but the government of Canada favoured the rival [[Grand Trunk Railway]]. Also the end of the [[Recession|Depression]] (1857â1862) and population dips downwards in Hamilton and the city could not meet the interest on its bonds, many of which were held by British investors. To save the city from its creditors temporarily, [[Henry Beasley]] removes the assessment rolls, thus preventing a levy of special tax. Foundries and machine shops associated with the Great Western Railway failed and several established wholesalers closed their accounts. Daniel C. Gunn's locomotive works went bankrupt, but the manufacturers of farm implements and stoves-the mainstays of iron foundries- were able to weather the crisis. Those owned by [[Dennis Moore (Canadian manufacturer)|Dennis Moore]] and the Copp brothers endured, but their employees suffered wage cuts and layoffs. Canadian patent laws and the underemployed workers skilled in machinist trades lured an important new industrial enterprise from the U.S.A.- the manufacture of sewing machines by [[Richard Wanzer]]. From this development there evolved the ready-made clothing industry, which [[William Eli Sanford]] introduced locally. From judicial village to commercial town to railway centre, Hamilton moves to an ever stronger dependency on industry.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1864â First Board of Trade- Hon. [[Isaac Buchanan]], President. 27 churches and 77 taverns in the city.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1867â Confederation of Canada.
* 1868â Hottest day ever recorded in Hamilton as the thermometer hits 41.4 Â°C <ref name=VANHAM>{{cite book|title=Vanished Hamilton Calender|first=Margaret |last=Houghton |publisher=North Shore Publishing|year=2006|isbn= 1-896899-39-0}}</ref>
* 1869â On Wednesday, November 3, 1869, in a room above George Lee's Fruit Store, the Hamilton Football Club was formed.<ref name="Football Canada timeline">{{Cite web|url=http://www.footballcanada.com/history_timeline.asp|title=Canadian Football Timelines (1860 â present)|accessdate=2006-12-23|publisher=[[Football Canada]] |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070228064050/http://www.footballcanada.com/history_timeline.asp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-02-28}}</ref> Hamilton Football Clubs have captured the [[Grey Cup]] in every decade of the 20th century, a feat matched in pro sport by only one other franchise, the [[Montreal Canadiens]].<ref name="Football Canada timeline" />
==1870â1879== * 1870â1870s decade; Confederation era Hamilton boosters lose a commercial and financial edge to Toronto and consciously shift to the economic strategy of attracting industry.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1870â Daily [[temperature]] published.<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1872â The [[Nine Hour Movement]] is born, Hamilton unionists urge government to limit working hours to nine per day.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1872 â the [[Bank of Hamilton]] was established. It lasted until 1924. The Bank of Hamilton merged with The Commerce (later to become the [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce]], or CIBC) on January 2, 1924. It was one of the last surviving banks in Canada that was not headquartered in [[Toronto]] or Montreal.<ref name=BANKHAM>{{cite web| title = Mergers and Amalgamations, The Canadian Bank of Commerce| url=http://www.cibc.com/ca/inside-cibc/history/mergers-amalgamations/bank-of-commerce.html CIBC| accessdate = 2007-03-10}}</ref>
* 1873â The Hamilton Football Club played its first game against the recently-formed [[Toronto Argonauts]], which the Argonauts won. It was in that game that the Hamilton players first wore their colours of yellow and black. Hamilton won the rematch the following Saturday, and it was in the reporting of that game that they were first referred to as the Tigers.
* 1874â The [[Hamilton Street Railway]] (HSR) began offering horse-drawn public transportation.<ref name=HSRhistory>{{cite web|url=http://home.cc.umanitoba.ca/~wyatt/alltime/hamilton-on.html |title=Hamilton Street Railway History|accessdate=2007-01-07}}</ref><ref name=HSRhistory2>{{cite web|url= http://hamiltontransithistory.host-ed.net/index.html|title= Hamilton Transit History|accessdate=2007-01-08}}</ref>
* 1876â First time all the [[Irish people|Irish]] got together in Hamilton to celebrate March 17- St. Patrick's day.<ref name=Irish>{{cite web| title =St. Patrick's Day in Hamilton: 1876| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/St.+Patricks+Day.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* 1877â June 20, 1877â First commercial telephone service (Fire Department) in Canada began in Hamilton, Ontario.<ref name="headlake"/> Hugh Cossart Baker, Jr. learned of [[Alexander Graham Bell]]'s invention in 1877 at the Philadelphia International Exposition and from there decided to test the communication tool in Hamilton.<ref name=HAM100>{{cite book|title=The Hamiltonians, 100 Fascinating Lives |first=Margaret |last=Houghton |publisher=James Lorimer & Company Ltd., Publishers Toronto|page=6|year=2003|isbn= 1-55028-804-0}}</ref>
* 1877â Robert Smiley, the founding publisher of [[The Spectator]], sold the newspaper to [[William Southam]] in 1877 as the first link in the Southam newspaper chain.<ref name=memproj>{{cite press release| title =The Hamilton Memory Project| publisher =The Hamilton Spectator- Souvenir Edition|page=MP38| date = June 10, 2006| accessdate = 2006-12-30}}</ref>
* 1877â Hamilton population at 32,641.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1878â The first telephone exchange in the British Empire was opened in Hamilton. (Hugh Cossart Baker, Jr.)<ref name="headlake"/><ref name="HAM100"/>
* 1879â May 15- Hamilton is the site of the first commercial long distance telephone line in the British Empire. (Hugh Cossart Baker, Jr.), Hamilton to [[Dundas, Ontario|Dundas]].<ref name="headlake"/><ref name="HAM100"/>
==1880â1889== * 1880â [[McMaster University]] opens up in Toronto (''Bloor Street'' campus). Eventually moves to Hamilton in 1930.<ref name="headlake"/>
* 1880â Apr 29- Hugh Cossart Baker, Jr. of Hamilton, Ontario received charter to build a national telephone company. It was called ''The Hamilton Telephone Company'' and this was the charter that enabled the creation of the [[Bell Telephone]] Company in Canada. Hugh Cossart Baker, Jr. became the manager of the Ontario division until he retired in 1909.<ref name="HAM100"/>
* 1880â Trained [[nursing]] introduced in city hospital.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1881â [[Thomas Willson]], Hamilton inventor, designed and patented the first electric [[arc lamps]] in 1881.<ref name=WILLSON>{{cite web| title =Biography of Thomas Willson| url=http://www.biographi.ca/EN/ShowBio.asp?BioId=41897| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1881â First public [[telephones]] installed.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1882â Ernest DâIsraeli Smith, ([[E.D. Smith]]) after being frustrated by paying to have his fruit transported from the Stoney Creek area, had founded a company in 1882 to market directly to wholesalers and eliminate the middleman. E.D. Smith & Sons Ltd. continues operating today, and has since the early 20th century has sold manufactured preserves and jams. Its namesake founder served as the Conservative MP for Wentworth around the turn of the 20th century.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1883â Asphalt sidewalks on main streets.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1886â [[Florence Lawrence]], "Hollywood's first movie star" is born January 2, 1886 in Hamilton, Ontario.<ref name=florence>{{cite book| last = Brown| first = Kelly R.,| title =Florence Lawrence, the Biograph Girl: America's First Movie Star | year = 1991| isbn = 0-7864-0627-5}}</ref>
* 1888â Group of English businessmen visiting the city nicknamed it the "Birmingham of Canada."<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1889â Wentworth Historical Society is founded. (8 January 1889)<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>

* 1889â [[Robert B. Harris]] (along with his brother John M. Harris) establish the Hamilton Herald newspaper in 1889. Begins publishing on August 1 becoming Hamilton's first one-cent newspaper. Newspaper lasts until 1936.<ref name=HAMBIO2>{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Hamilton Biography (Vol II, 1876â1924)|first=Thomas Melville |last=Bailey|publisher=W.L. Griffin Ltd|year=1991}}</ref>
==1890â1899== [[Image:Thb locomotive 22.jpg|thumb|right|TH&B locomotive No. 22 with crew, circa 1900â1910.]] [[Image:1899Winton.jpg|thumb|1899 Winton]] [[Image:The Tigers of Hamilton football team.jpg|thumb|The [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats|Hamilton Tigers]] circa 1906]] * 1890â First organized Hockey Game held in Hamilton; Bank of Hamilton VS Knox, Morgan. * 1890â First Bowling alley in the City opens at back of the ''J.W. MacDonald Tobacco shop'', (66 [[James Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|James Street North]]).<ref name="Bank"/>

* 1892â The [[Toronto, Hamilton and Buffalo Railway]] began operations.<ref name=THBHIST>{{cite web|url=http://www.thbrailway.ca/|title=Toronto, Hamilton and Buffalo Railway Historical Society|accessdate=2007-01-28}}</ref>

Prime Minister Sir [[John Sparrow David Thompson|John Thompson]] in attendance.<ref name=statue>{{cite web| title = Sir John A. Macdonald statue, 1893| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Sir+John+A.+Macdonald+Statue.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-08}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
* 1893â Hamilton Electric Light Co. Electrify the street railway.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1894â ''Harvey Park'' was named after ''Colonel John Harvey'', a British Officer during the War of 1812. The name was accepted by Hamilton City Council 11 June 1894. (situated just West of ''Dundurn Park'').<ref name="HAMTIMES"/>
* 1894â Hamilton Herald newspaper and cigar store owner Billy Carroll established the Around the Bay Road Race. Although it is not a proper [[marathon]], it is the longest continuously held long distance foot race in North America.<ref name="HAMBIO1"/>
* 1895â Wentworth Incline railway begins operation on August, 1895. (1895â1936)<ref name="HSRhistory"/><ref name="HSRhistory2"/>
* 1895â The [[TH&B]] Railway came into Hamilton in 1895. A railway tunnel was then constructed from ''Queen'' to ''Park Street'' to cut down on the noise, pollution and disruption for the wealthy families who lived South of Jackson Street in the ''Durand'' neighbourhood.<ref name=LOCKES>{{cite book|title=Up and Down Locke Street South|first=Ann & Bill |last=Manson |publisher=North Shore Publishing|year=1999|isbn= 1-896899-08-0}}</ref>
* 1896â Sir [[John Morison Gibson]] forms The ''Dominion Power and Transmission Company'', that brought hydroelectric power, for the first time, to Hamilton, from their plant, at DeCrew Falls.<ref name="HAMBIO2-p143">{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Hamilton Biography (Vol II, 1876â1924)|first=Thomas Melville |last=Bailey|publisher=W.L. Griffin Ltd|page=143|year=1991}}</ref>
* 1896â Hamilton Radial Electric Railway extended across Beach Strip. (7 September 1896).<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1896â Hamilton [[firefighters]] unionized.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1897â [[John M. Lyle]], Hamilton architect in the late 19th century and early 20th century, designs [[New York Public Library]] in 1897. (Later went on to design the [[Royal Alexandra Theatre]], in Toronto (1907) and [[Union Station (Toronto)]] 1914â1921).<ref name=Lyle>{{cite web| title = Canadian Encyclopedia Biography of John M. Lyle| url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0004816| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1897â [[Adelaide Hoodless]], was a Canadian educational reformer who founded the international womenâs organization known as the Womenâs Institutes in 1897.<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1897â [[Westinghouse Electric (1886)|Westinghouse]] established in Hamilton. first Westinghouse operation outside of the U.S.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1898â The "Five Johns", (John Cameron, [[John Dickenson (Canadian politician)]], John Morison Gibson, John Moodie, Sr. and John Sutherland), form ''The Cataract Power Co. Ltd.'' introducing electric power to Hamilton in 1898. On August 25, 1898, power was sent twenty seven miles from ''DeCew Falls'', [[St. Catharines]], using water from the old [[Welland Canal]]. New industries, such as the forerunners of the Steel Co. of Canada ([[Stelco]]) and Canadian Westinghouse, were attracted here by the cheaper, more efficient power. One time this Company controlled hydro power from [[Brantford, Ontario|Brantford]] to St. Catharines, including the Hamilton Street Railway and the area's radial lines. Back then the city's nickname was "''The Electric City.''"<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1898â The first automobile driven in Canada was by textile manufacturer [[John Moodie]] in 1898; A one-cylinder [[Winton (automobile)|Winton]] he imported from [[Cleveland]]. John Moodie was also one of the founders of Canada's automobile club, the [[Hamilton Automobile Club]], which was founded in 1903 when there were 18 cars in town. By 1920, there were 6,000 and Hamilton's ratio of one car for every 15 people was higher than that of New York, Chicago, Boston or Toronto.<ref name=memproj />
* 1899â [[Thomas Bain]] in 1899 becomes the [[Speaker of the Canadian House of Commons]] in Ottawa.<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1899â Dundurn becomes a city park and the [[Victorian Order of Nurses]] begin work in Hamilton.<ref name="SAGA"/>
==1900â1909== [[Image:John Morison Gibson.jpg|thumb|right|Sir [[John Morison Gibson]] in 1908]] [[Image:Robert Stanley Weir 1899.png|thumb|right|[[Robert Stanley Weir]]]] * 1902â [[International Harvester]] is the second major United States industry to locate in Hamilton.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1902â Canadian [[Otis Elevator Company]] is formed (August 22)<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1903â ''Hamilton Automobile Club'' (was the first in Canada) founded by John Moodie.<ref name=memproj />
* 1903â ''Canadian Canners Limited'' formed. (Originally known as ''Canadian Canners Consolidated Companies Limited'')<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1904â [[George Klein (inventor)|George Klein]], (born: August 15, 1904) â often called "The most productive inventor in Canada in the 20th century."<ref name=Klein>{{cite web| title = Canadian Encyclopedia Biography of George Klein| url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0004345| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1906â Hamilton east elected Ontario's first independent labour candidate, [[Allan Studholme]], who held the seat until his death in 1919.
* 1906â Local boy [[William Sherring]] won an [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] gold medal at [[Athens]] for the marathon.<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1906â "One big reason" for almost 75% increase in the population of Hamilton between 1901 and 1912, boasted Sir John Morison Gibson of ''Dominion Power and Transmission Company'', was "Cheap Electric Power Furnished By Us." This simplistic explanation for the development of Hamilton in the early 20th century leaves much unexamined, but one conclusion cannot be disputed. In the perception of the Hamilton public, a view certainly fostered by Gibson and his fellow hydroelectric promoters, Hamilton was no longer regarded the Birmingham or the Pittsburgh of Canada Hamilton was now, as the title of a 1906 promotional booklet on the city proudly proclaimed, '''"The Electric City."'''<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1906â Hamilton Street Railway strike of 1906. Violent strike turns ugly and one of the few times in Hamilton's history that the Riot Act is read and enforced.<ref name=hsrstrike>{{cite web| title = Hamilton Street Railway strike of 1906| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Commerce+and+Industry.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-11 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060908121255/http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/Commerce+and+Industry.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-09-08}}</ref>
* 1908â Sir John Morison Gibson (1842â1929) becomes the Lieutenant-Governor of Ontario (1908â1914). from Hamilton.<ref name="Bank"/>
* 1908â [[Robert Stanley Weir]], best remembered as the author of the English lyrics to ''[[O Canada]].'' His verses were first published in 1908, he spoke of them as representing ''a humble effort to do a great thing: to supply Canadians with a National Song; not to usurp others more or less in vogue, but to take place with them in the minstrelsy of our country.'' The song became widely used as a national anthem, was approved as such by Canada's parliament in 1967, and was with minor changes to the lyrics, formally legislated as such in 1980.<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1908â [[Robert Kerr (athlete)|Robert Kerr]], Irish-Canadian sprinter. He won the gold medal in the 200 metres and the bronze medal in the 100 metres at the 1908 Summer Olympics.<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1909â On 24 May 1909 a [[Coney Island]]-type amusement Park was opened in Hamilton. It was known as ''Maple Leaf Park'' and was bounded by [[Barton Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Barton Street]] (north), [[Ottawa Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Ottawa Street]] (east), [[Cannon Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Cannon Street]] (south), ''Rosslyn Avenue'' (west). It failed to attract enough visitors to keep the gates open and only lasted a year. Investors of the Park sold the land to local real estate speculators for $25,000 interested in the property because the land itself was a valuable commodity in the booming East Hamilton market.<ref name="HAMTIMES"/>
==1910â1919== * 1910â Steel Company of Canada (Stelco) is formed.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1910â [[Andrew Ross (businessman)|Andrew Ross]], local Hamilton businessman builds the [[Barton Street Arena]]; future home of NHL [[Hamilton Tigers (ice hockey)|Hamilton Tigers]].<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1910â The Royal Hotel (later renamed the Royal Connaught Hotel) is constructed on King Street.<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1911â Hamilton hosted its first Aviation Meet at Aviation Park, hastily created on the Arthur O'Heir Survey, adjacent to the Tuckett Farm and Burlington Bay.<ref name="headlake"/>

* 1912â Hamilton is second only to Montreal in shipping. (4.5 miles of dockage)<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1912â First ever Grey Cup victory by a football team from Hamilton (4th ever Grey Cup). The [[Hamilton Alerts]] defeat the Toronto Argonauts 11-to-4. Game was played in Hamilton at the [[A.A.A. Grounds]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2010}}
* 1912â [[Jack Kent Cooke]], born in Hamilton in 1912â was a Canadian-American entrepreneur who became one of the most widely-known executives in North American professional sports. He owned the [[Washington Redskins]] ([[NFL]]), the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] ([[NBA]]), and the [[Los Angeles Kings]] ([[NHL]]), and built The Forum in [[Inglewood, California]].<ref name=cooke>{{cite web| title = Jack Kent Cooke: A Career Biography| url=http://www.jackkentcookefoundation.org/jkcf_web/content.aspx?page=6536536| accessdate = 2007-01-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> [[Image:Andrew Carnegie, three-quarter length portrait, seated, facing slightly left, 1913.jpg|thumb|[[Andrew Carnegie]], 1913.]]
* 1912â Dr. Alfred Pain of Hamilton drowns after the [[RMS Titanic|Titanic]] hits an iceberg. (14 April 1912).<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1913â After receiving a grant from [[Andrew Carnegie]] of New York the city of Hamilton builds a brand new Library on the south side of Main Street West, across the street from the old Library. It is officially opened by the Lieutenant Governor [and Hamiltonian], Sir John Morison Gibson on May 5, 1913.<ref name="Library"/>
* 1913â Increased population and prosperity prompted a building boom. As a publicity stunt and raffle, workers and contractors built a house in a day in 1913 which was later featured in a [[Ripleyâs Believe It or Not]] cartoon.<ref name=memproj />
* 1913â the [[Procter & Gamble]] Manufacturing Company (based in Cincinnati) purchased land in Hamilton. This event marks beginning of company's operations outside the U.S.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1914â Sir [[John Strathearn Hendrie]] (1857â1923) becomes the Lieutenant-Governor of Ontario (1914â1919). from Hamilton.<ref name="Bank"/>
* 1914â Construction starts on [[Procter & Gamble]] Hamilton plant, which cost $1 million and consisted of seven buildings: the Crisco building, the boiler house, the gas plant, the soap building, the hardening plant, the kettle and glycerin house, and the machine shop.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1914â Hamilton is connected to Toronto by the first concrete highway built in Canada, Highway 2<ref name="memproj"/>
* 1915â Procter & Gamble officially opens Hamilton plant, employing 75 workers who made six different products.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1915â ''Herkimer Apartments'', on the corner of [[Bay Street (Hamilton)|Bay Street South]] and ''Herkimer Street'', was the first Hamilton apartment installed with an elevator, which ran from the basement to the fifth floor. Opened in July 1915.<ref name=HERKIMER>{{cite news | last = McGuinness| first = Eric| title = Hamilton Essentials: "When walk-ups were the norm"| publisher = The Hamilton Spectator| date = 2007-03-19| accessdate = 2007-06-04}}</ref>
* 1916â The [[Royal Connaught Hotel]] opened. (Construction of it started in 1914).<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1917â Gage Park opens up.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1919â Hoover Suction Sweeper Company builds a plant in Hamilton.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1919â Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of Canada is established.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1919â Bay Street, derives its name from its proximity to ''Hamilton Harbour'', which was once ''Burlington Bay''. In 1919, a Federal Order-In-Council changed the name of ''Burlington Bay'' to ''Hamilton Harbour''.<ref name=HAMNAMES>{{cite book|title=Hamilton Street Names: An Illustrated Guide|first=Margaret |last=Houghton|publisher=James Lorimer & Co. Ltd.|year=2002|isbn= 1-55028-773-7}}</ref>
* 1919â Civic Stadium built.<ref name="SAGA"/>
==1920â1929== * 1920â Hamilton gets an NHL team called the Hamilton Tigers, but then the team folds after a player's strike in 1925. Players get bought up by [[New York City]] bootleggers and the team there is named the [[New York Americans]] and become the very first pro sports team to play out of the newly built [[Madison Square Garden]] in downtown [[Manhattan]].<ref name=Tigers>{{cite book| last = Wesley| first = Sam, David| title = Hamilton's Hockey Tigers| publisher = James Lorimer & Company Ltd.| year = 2005| isbn = 1550288873}}</ref>
* 1921â Pantages Theatre opens up on King Street, (between [[Catharine Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Catharine Street]] and ''Mary Street''), with a seating capacity of 3,500 made it the largest theatre in Canada at the time. Renamed ''The Palace Theatre'' in 1930. It closed down in 1972.<ref name="HAMTIMES"/>
* 1921â The city's population grows to 114,000 making it Canada's 5th largest city.<ref name="HAMBIO2"/>
* 1922â [[CKOC]] radio station starts up. Today it is the oldest radio station in English Canada; second oldest overall. On the air since May 1, 1922<ref name=CKOC>{{cite web| title = CKOC Radio Official web site| url=http://www.oldies1150.com/ | accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1922â Prior to the 1922â23 season, the NHL would hold its Governors meeting at the Royal Connaught Hotel on King Street, where the visiting NHL teams who came to town to play against the Hamilton Tigers stayed as well.<ref name=TIGERS>{{cite book|title=Hamilton's Hockey Tigers |first=Sam & David |last=Wesley |publisher=James Lorimer & Company Ltd.|year=2005|isbn= 1550288873}}</ref>
* 1922â Beech-Nut Packing Company (makers of the [[Life Savers]] candy), establishes Canadian operations in Hamilton.<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1923â On 29 March 1923, real estate agents and politicians announce the winning name, (Name the neighbourhood contest), at the ''Royal Connaught Hotel'' in downtown Hamilton. 6,170 people were gathered for the official announcement. Rev. Canon Percival Lawson Spencer won $200.00 for his submission of the "Westdale" name. Other names that were seriously considered for the neighbourhood include, ''Westhome'', ''Vimy Ridge'', ''Bridgeton'', ''Woodlands Park'', ''Surrey Park'' and ''Bridgeview''.<ref name="HAMTIMES"/>
* 1923â Westinghouse in Hamilton was the first company in Canada to manufacture radios (1923) and electric air cleaners (1944).<ref name=HISINDI/>
* 1923â [[Babe Dye]] becomes NHL scoring champion, repeats feat in 1925.<ref name=CHATLAS>{{cite book|title=The Canadian Hockey Atlas|first=Stephen|last=Cole|publisher=Doubleday Canada|year=2006|isbn=978-0-385-66093-8 (0-385-66093-6)}}</ref>
* 1923â Scottish Rite Cathedral built.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1924â The second Lister Block building erected. (The first one built in 1886 was destroyed by fire in 1923).<ref name=SAGA/>
* 1925â First traffic lights in Canada go into operation at ''the Delta.'' (11 June 1925).<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1925â Hamilton Tigers finish first overall in the NHL but players refuse to participate in playoffs. At end of season team folds and players move to New York and join the NHL's newest hockey club; the New York Americans.<ref name="Tigers"/>
* 1926â First Motor bus on Hamilton streets, 26 August (1926 â present).<ref name="HSRhistory"/>
* 1927â [[CHML]] began operations in 1927 as a response to censorship of political discussions by Hamilton's first radio station, CKOC. The original owners were Maple Leaf Radio Company, and the "HML" in the callsign stood for "Hamilton Maple Leaf".<ref name=memproj />
* 1927 Jack V. Elliot established the ''Elliot Airport'' on the old Ghent homestead, running from the Radial Line to the Bay.<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1927â First airmail flight to Hamilton. (24 August 1927).<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1928â Eileen Vollick, Aviator, Fascinated by aviation from childhood this daring young woman enrolled in the Jack V. Elliot Aviation School in Hamilton, Ontario. On March 31, 1928 she passed the federal aviation test and become the first Canadian woman to earn a private pilot's certificate.<ref name=EVOLLIK>{{cite web| title =Famous Canadian Women, Aviation: Eileen Vollick| url=http://famouscanadianwomen.com/on%20the%20job/aviators.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-23}}</ref>
* 1929â On May 24, 1929 , a great ceremony was attended by numerous citizens of Hamilton . The unveiling of the United Empire Loyalists statue, which was a generous gift to the city by Mr. Stanley Mills, brought great cheers from the crowd gathered outside the Wentworth County Court House.<ref name=loyalists>{{cite web| title = United Empire Loyalists Statue- 1929| url=http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/United+Empire+Loyalist+Statue.htm| accessdate = 2007-01-08 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070428124543/http://www.myhamilton.ca/myhamilton/LibraryServices/Localhistory/United+Empire+Loyalist+Statue.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-04-28}}</ref>
* 1929â Built for $1,000,000, Hamilton's first skyscraper; The Pigott Building: 18-floors, {{convert|210|ft|m}}. Originally an office building, the Pigott Building is now used for condominiums.<ref name=pigott>{{cite web| title = The Pigott Building- 1929| url=http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=pigottbuilding-hamilton-canada| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
==1930â1939== [[Image:Entrance CCTK Hamilton.jpg|thumb|right|[[Christ the King Cathedral (Hamilton)|Christ the King Cathedral]]]] [[Image:Syl Apps.jpg|thumb|right|[[Syl Apps]]]] * 1930â The first [[British Empire Games]] â now the [[Commonwealth Games]] â were held in Hamilton in 1930 as a result of the efforts of [[Melville Marks Robinson]].<ref name=memproj2>{{cite press release| title = Tigertown Triumphs| publisher =The Hamilton Spectator-Memory Project (Souvenir Edition) page MP56| date =2006-06-10| accessdate = 2006-12-30}}</ref>
* 1930â McMaster University moves to Hamilton, Ontario from Toronto.<ref name=HAMBIO3>{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Hamilton Biography (Vol III, 1925â1939)|first=Thomas Melville |last=Bailey|publisher=W.L. Griffin Ltd|year=1992}}</ref>
* 1930â [[Besha Starkman]] ([[Rocco Perri]]'s wife) murdered on 13 August 1930.<ref name="HAMBIO3"/>
* 1931â Built in 1931, [[Westdale Secondary School]] was immediately deemed the largest composite school in the [[British Empire]], having cost $1.3 million to build and consisting of 4.7 hectares of building, grounds and athletic fields.<ref name=WESTDALE>{{cite press release| title = Celebrity High: Westdale Secondary Alumni| publisher = The Hamilton Spectator| date = 2006-05-19| url = http://www.hamiltonspectator.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=hamilton/Layout/Article_Type1&c=Article&cid=1147989017565&call_pageid=1020420665036&col=1014656511815| accessdate = 2007-01-23}}</ref>
* 1931â Canada's first birth control clinic was in Hamilton in 1931, as the advocates of birth control, led by Mary (Chambers) Hawkins, the American wife of a prominent city executive, and aided by some of Hamilton society's leading women, it aimed to meet the needs of people whose health and family lives suffered tremendously during the [[Great Depression]].<ref name="HAMBIO3"/>
* 1931â Trains no longer block traffic as [[James Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|James Street]] underpass is completed. (3 December 1931).<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1932â [[Red Horner]], pro hockey player, helps the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] win their first [[Stanley Cup]] in 1932.<ref name="CHATLAS"/>
* 1932â [[Ray Lewis (runner)|Ray Lewis]], captures Bronze medal at 1932 Summer Olympics in L.A. (Track & Field), becoming the very first Canadian-born Black Olympic medalist.<ref name="memproj2"/>
* 1932â [[James Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|James Street]] Incline railway closes and permanently abandoned on May 14, 1932. (1892â1932)<ref name="HSRhistory"/><ref name="HSRhistory2"/>
* 1933â [[Filtration]] plant opened.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1933â Christ the King Cathedral, a [[Roman Catholic]] church, was consecrated on December 19, 1933.<ref name=christking>{{cite web|url= http://www.christthekingcathedral.org/history.htm|title= Christ the King Cathedral History|accessdate=2007-01-10 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070205212034/http://www.christthekingcathedral.org/history.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-02-05}}</ref>
* 1933â [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] allows the city of Hamilton to use the name, [[Royal Botanical Gardens (Ontario)|Royal Botanical Gardens]]. (19 May 1933).<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1934â Hamilton is the birthplace of [[Canadian Tire]]. Two brothers John W. Billes and Alfred J. Biles in 1934 open up first associate store in Hamilton, Ontario.<ref name=memproj />
* 1936â [[Wentworth Street (Hamilton, Ontario)|Wentworth]] Incline railway stops operating on August 15, 1936. (1895â1936)<ref name="HSRhistory"/><ref name="HSRhistory2"/> The first day, the public was allowed free access up and down the line. By the time the ''Wentworth Street'' Incline made its last trip on 16 August 1936, it was estimated that nearly 20,000,000 trips had been made up and down the line.<ref name="HAMTIMES"/>
* 1937â [[Syl Apps]], legendary Toronto Maple Leafs captain who led the Leafs to three Stanley Cups and McMaster University alumnus, wins the Calder trophy in 1937 as the top rookie in the [[National Hockey League]].<ref name="CHATLAS"/>
==1940â1949== * 1940â The June 1940 issue of ''Canadian Transportation'', in an article titled 'The Transit Service in Hamilton', stated that 72-passenger [[street cars]] of all-steel construction, and fitted for one-man operation, as well as 33 [[buses]] were in operation when it was written. The article went on to say that the Hamilton Street Railway had 27.97 route miles of electric [[railway]].<ref name="HSRhistory"/><ref name="HSRhistory2"/>
* 1940â [[Harry Crerar]] was a Canadian general and became the country's "leading field commander" in [[World War II]].<ref name=HCrerar>{{cite book|title=The Generals : the Canadian Army's Senior Commanders in the Second World War |first=J.L.|last=Granatstein|year=Toronto 1993|isbn=0-7737-5728-7}}</ref>
* 1940â John C. Munro Hamilton International Airport; The airport was originally built in 1940 as the Mount Hope Airport, a [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] base. After the war, the airport gradually shifted towards civil use, The military ceased using it as a base in 1964.<ref name=airport2>{{cite web| title = Airport Information: Facts| publisher= John C. Munro Hamilton International Airport| url= http://www.flyhi.ca/airport-information/facts/ | accessdate = 2010-10-23}}</ref>
* 1941â The [[Royal Botanical Gardens (Ontario)|Royal Botanical Gardens]] was established as an independent entity in 1941 by an act of the provincial government, but the project's origins are traceable to the late 1920s when the City of Hamilton began acquiring land for the beautification of the cityâs northwest entrance.<ref name=rbg>{{cite web| title = Royal Botanical Gardens Official web site| url=http://www.rbg.ca/| accessdate = 2007-01-10}}</ref>
* 1943â [[Jackie Callura]], was a Canadian featherweight boxer and became the world featherweight champion by defeating Jackie Wilson in 1943.<ref name="memproj2"/>
* 1944â Civic bathing beach was closed by the Department of Health.<ref name="SAGA"/>
* 1944â On 23 April 1944, Rocco Perri was seen for the last time in Hamilton, Ontario. As one [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] officer concluded in a 1954 interview, "We won't find his body until the Bay dries up."<ref name="HAMBIO3-p143">{{cite book|title=Dictionary of Hamilton Biography (Vol III, 1925â1939)|first=Thomas Melville |last=Bailey|publisher=W.L. Griffin Ltd|page=143|year=1992}}</ref>
* 1944â An earthquake damaged St. Paul's Church spire. (5 September 1944).<ref name="VANHAM"/>
* 1944â ''Sam Lawrence Park'' can be found on the western end of [[Concession Street (Hamilton, Ontario)]]. Prior to 1944, this property was the Webb Quarry. In February 1944, The City of Hamilton was given {{convert|3|acre|m2}} of land for park use by [[Thomas Hambly Ross]], MP (Hamilton East), and his wife Olive. The park was originally named Ross Park, then renamed Patton Park in 1946, in honour of captain [[John MacMillan Stevenson Patton]], a Hamiltonian who risked his life during World War II by detonating an unexploded bomb. For this exploit he received the first [[George Cross]] for valour. In 1960, the park was renamed to honour [[Sam Lawrence]]. During 1990 to 1994, Sam Lawrence Park underwent a major upgrading that included repairing the stone walls, installing new walkways, site lighting, site furniture, and the redevelopment of the major rock gardens.<ref name="HAM100"/>

The fight was over union recognition, a 40-hour work week and wages. With the help of Hamilton's community this struggle changed Canadian labour history. It forced employers to accept [[collective bargaining]] and helped start a mass trade-union movement in Canada.<ref name=memproj58>{{cite press release| title =The Hamilton Memory Project; Local 1005 History| publisher =The Hamilton Spectator- Souvenir Edition page MP58| date = June 10, 2006| accessdate = 2007-01-15}}</ref>
* 1946â [[Evelyn Dick]] was arrested for murder after local children in Hamilton, Ontario found the torso of her missing estranged husband. The head and limbs had been sawn from his body and evidence that they had been burned in the furnace of her home later surfaced. She was convicted of the murder in 1946 and sentenced to hang. However, lawyer [[John Josiah Robinette|J.J. Robinette]] appealed her case and won an eventual acquittal. However, in the meantime, the decayed remains of Evelyn's baby boy were found encased in cement under the floorboards of her home. She was convicted of the murder in 1947 and sentenced to 11 years in prison. Evelyn was released from prison in 1958 and quickly disappeared from public view.<ref name="memproj"/>

* 1978â August 7: Hamilton held a round of the Formula Atlantic Championship. The insurance company demanded that the metal containers that formed part of the portable barrier system be filled with sand. In the haste to get this done in time, sand was dumped all over the road. The resulting delay led to the whole event being run in just half a day. Following 30 minutes of practice, a shortened qualifying session was held for 48 minutes, although there was basically only one line due to the sand still lying on the circuit. Finally, at 8pm the race itself was started. The race was originally scheduled for 70 laps. There was a safety car period after an early three car incident. The race was eventually red flagged after 39 laps due to darkness. 1982 Formula One World Champion [[Keke Rosberg]] won the race. In 1983, the Park Street section of track between York and King was removed to build [[Copps Coliseum]]. The paddock area on the track was located where Hamilton Place currently stands.<ref>[http://ellis.v12racing.net/racingcircuits/racingcircuits/]</ref>
